thread.title: Australian film Oddball, starring Shane Jacobson, has Red Dog box office in its sights
thread.title_full: Australian film Oddball, starring Shane Jacobson, has Red Dog box office in its sights

author: Vicky Roach
title: Australian film Oddball, starring Shane Jacobson, has Red Dog box office in its sights
text:
Video Image Oddball - Trailer 2:01 The true story about an eccentric chicken farmer who, with the help of his granddaughter, trains his mischievous dog Oddball to protect a wild penguin sanctuary from fox attacks and in the process tries to reunite his family and save their seaside town.
January 1st 1970 46 years ago /video/video.news.com.au/Entertainment/ Shaggy dog story ... a scene from Oddball.
Vicky Roach News Corp Australia Network RED dog took a whopping $21.5 million bite out of the box office. And Happy Feet danced its way into the top five Australian films of all time.
Just imagine what a story featuring both a charismatic canine AND a rookery of cute-as-a-button fairy penguins could do.
Oddball , which has the added bonus of popular comedian/actor Shane Jacobson in the lead human role, opened at No 5 at the Aussie box office over the weekend with $1 million in ticket sales.
By Tuesday, the family film, based on the true story of Warrnambool chicken farmer Swampy Marsh, had more doubled that figure ($2,104,165), climbing all the way to the No 2 spot (behind Sony’ Pixels.)
While it’s still early days yet for the homegrown crowd-pleaser, which has been released to coincide with the September school holidays, past experience would suggest that the filmmakers are on to a winning formula.
Double the appeal ... Meet Oddball’s leading couple. Source: Supplied
Dogs, penguins, horses and pigs all punch well above their weight in the list of the top dozen Australian films of all time.
Babe brought home the most bacon — $36.8 million — to occupy the No 3 spot (after Australia and Crocodile Dundee).
But Happy Feet chased its curly tail all the way into fourth place ($31.8 million).
Red Dog , based on the true story of a cattle dog that united a disparate Pilbara mining community, hitched a ride to No 9.
Star attraction ... The late kelpie Koko as Red Dog. Source: Supplied
The Brumbies were the real stars of The Man From Snowy River (1982), which still sits comfortably astride No 11 — and of course its $17.2 million tally has not been adjusted for inflation.
“There’s a maxim in Hollywood: I don’t care what happens in this film as long as the dog doesn’t die,’’ says Richard Harris, head of Screen Australia’s Business and Audience Department.
“Animals have a universal appeal. I think people — and particularly children — respond to them in a way that’s really deep and emotional . “
“They provide an easy way in. So you can tell stories about our own struggles, but tell them through the lens of an animal.”
Enduring appeal ... Blinky Bill as voiced by Ryan Kwanten. Source: Supplied
Supporting Harris’s thesis, albeit on a more modest scale, was Blinky Bill The Movie. It opened at No 7 over the weekend with a solid $250,000 tally — not bad for a (by Pixar standards) low-budget animation aimed at preschool audiences and likely to make most of its money in ancillary markets.
The weekend figures consolidate upon a bumper year for Australian productions, which posted a 6.1 per cent share of the overall box office last week — the best result in 14 years.
Crowd-pleasers such as Mad Max: Fury Road ($21.65 million), The Water Diviner ($10.18 million), Paper Planes ($9.65 million) and Last Cab to Darwin ($6.76 million) have contributed to the current $50-million plus tally.
One of a kind ... Mumble lets his feet do the talking in Happy Feet. Source: Supplied
But Screen Australia’s research department does sound a cautionary note for the upcoming Red Dog prequel Blue Dog , which is scheduled for a December 26, 2016 release.
Babe Pig in the City took a fraction of its predecessor’s box office ($7.7 million). Happy Feet Two ’s performance was even more disappointing ($10.69 million) in relative terms.
